docs.lead_paragraph: Trial lawyers contribute heavily to state and Federal politicians, largely because they want to block reforms that would eliminate excessive litigation that follows automobile accidents and other mishaps. For the most part they have succeeded, but their gain is the average driver's loss. Americans pay punishingly high premiums, much of which land in lawyers' bank accounts. Now, however, bipartisan proposals in Washington and New Jersey would give drivers, especially those who are poor, substantial relief. Most earlier proposals to cut down litigation costs would have restricted a victim's right to sue for recovery of ''pain and suffering'' damages -- intangible losses, say from permanent disfigurement, that exist over and above monetary costs like medical bills and lost earnings. The trial lawyers have swatted most of the plans aside with the justifiable argument that denying people access to the courtroom is not the American way.
docs.abstract: Editorial backs bipartisan proposal in Congress aimed at eliminating excessive litigation that follows automobile accidents and other mishaps (M)
docs.snippet: Trial lawyers contribute heavily to state and Federal politicians, largely because they want to block reforms that would eliminate excessive litigation that follows automobile accidents and other mishaps. For the most part they have succeeded, but...

docs.lead_paragraph: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve say they believe the economy is finely balanced between healthy growth and inflation, and they are almost certain to leave interest rates unchanged when they meet early next month to consider monetary policy for the first time in 1997. But in interviews and in speeches over the last week, four Federal Reserve governors and several of the regional Federal Reserve Bank presidents suggested that despite the current ideal combination of steady growth, low unemployment and low inflation, they were likely to move swiftly to raise rates if they saw any acceleration in wages or prices later in the year.

headline.main: Ideal Economy, but Fed Has Its Guard Up

docs.abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers say economy is finely balanced between healthy growth and inflation, and they do not expect to change interest rates when they meet to consider monetary policy for first time in 1997; four Federal Reserve governors and several regional Federal Reserve Bank presidents suggest they would move swiftly to raise rates if they see any acceleration in wages or prices later in year, despite current ideal combination of steady growth, low unemployment and low inflation; on Wall Street, emerging consensus is that Fed is growing increasingly wary of rising wages, and will raise rates, as early as March, in pre-emptive strike against inflation; comments from Federal Reserve officials Alice M Rivlin, Susan M Phillips, Edward W Kelley Jr and Laurence H Meyer (M)
docs.snippet: Policy makers at the Federal Reserve say they believe the economy is finely balanced between healthy growth and inflation, and they are almost certain to leave interest rates unchanged when they meet early next month to consider monetary policy for...

docs.lead_paragraph: The New York Times asked a variety of political and public figures the following question: ''If you could get the Democratic President and the Republican Congress to set aside their differences and get one thing done, what would it be?'' Here are some of their answers:

headline.main: Priorities for the Nation: Education and Housing

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for the last three years, are beginning to inch ahead and may be poised for a sharp rise, especially for small businesses, according to employers, actuaries and industry consultants. Employers across the country said their health care costs were headed for a 4 percent increase this year, according to a survey released yesterday. And some health care experts project 5 to 10 percent growth in medical costs in 1998.

headline.main: Health Care Costs Edging Up And a Bigger Surge Is Feared

docs.abstract: Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for last three years, are inching upward and may be poised for sharper rise, especially for small businesses; employers project 4 percent rise this year as managed care companies strive to make up for thin profits they tolerated while pushing for new members; other factors also remain, such as aging population and costly medical technology; alliances and mergers have also put doctors and hospitals in stronger position to demand higher fees; combined annual premiiums paid by employers and employees averaged $3,915 per employee in 1996; Labor Department reports consumer medical costs rose 3 percent, compared with 3.3 percent rise in overall consumer price index in 1996 (M)
docs.snippet: Medical costs, which have risen less than inflation for the last three years, are beginning to inch ahead and may be poised for a sharp rise, especially for small businesses, according to employers, actuaries and industry consultants.     Employers...

docs.lead_paragraph: As he stands on the threshold of his second inauguration, Bill Clinton poses a paradox for the party he leads. Like no Democrat since Franklin D. Roosevelt, he has managed to capture the White House for a second term. Yet he did so by accepting many basic principles of the Republicans, while staving off their most ambitious assaults on Government.
docs.abstract: Pres Clinton, on threshold of his second inauguration, poses paradox for party he leads; has managed to capture White House for second term, as no other Democrat since Franklin D Roosevelt, but did so by accepting many basic principles of Republicanism, while staving off most ambitious assaults on Government; was unable to carry Democrats back into control of Congress in November '96 elections, and has built much of political comeback on distancing himself equally from both parties; question is whether he stands as party of one or whether he can redefine Democrats and keep peace among factions that submerged differences in 1996 in interest of preventing Republicans from winning both Congress and White House; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As he stands on the threshold of his second inauguration, Bill Clinton poses a paradox for the party he leads.    Like no Democrat since Franklin D. Roosevelt, he has managed to capture the White House for a second term. Yet he did so by accepting...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Dr. Rita A. Moriatti's Jan. 11 Op-Ed article on the ''demise of the home-based practice of the family physician'' portrays the extinction of an idealistic ''Marcus Welby'' style of practice because of managed care. This scene, no doubt, is being repeated many times across the country. Although we can lament the passing of this practice style, we must realize that it is an anachronism. Whereas the citizens of Glendora, N.J., were blessed with a dedicated provider, large parts of our inner-city populations didn't have the opportunity to ring the doorbell of their doctor's private residence in cases of emergency.

headline.main: Managed Care Also Has Its Marcus Welbys

docs.abstract: Dr Andrwe Conti letter disputes Dr Rita A Moriatti's January 11 Op-Ed article on demise of family physician (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF a poll-taker were to ask me, right now, ''What's your favorite place in Great Britain?'' I would answer ''Accident and Emergency at St. Thomas's Hospital.'' I really would. During a recent two-week working visit to London, I landed in the blessed haven of A. & E. three times -- if you count a pause there on the way to physiotherapy. Each time it was like wandering into an exceptionally soothing TV hospital sitcom. All this began with what turned out to be a temporary ''stress-related heart problem.'' On my first day of work on my first BBC radio series, I found myself staring over the producer's shoulder at the digital tape-editing screen while the diagrams on it became strangely squiggly and my recorded voice strangely distant. With the feeling I was about to both faint and be sick (in the English sense, all over the floor), I tottered into a taxi and crossed the Thames to St. Thomas's Hospital.
docs.abstract: Article by Alice Furlaud recounts her unplanned visits to Accident and Emergency Room of hospital in London during recent trip to England; says several mishaps landed her in hospital and she was pleased with wonderful care she received, and at no cost to her; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal advisory panel has decided to recommend that Congress freeze Medicare payments to hospitals next year. It would be the first time in the history of the program that hospitals have not received an increase. In approving the recommendation, the panel said that hospitals had effectively controlled their costs, so that existing Medicare payment rates were generally adequate.

headline.main: MEDICARE PANEL ADVISES A FREEZE ON HOSPITAL PAY

docs.abstract: Prospective Payment Assessment Commission, a Federal advisory panel, recommends that Congress freeze Medicare payments to hospitals next year because hospitals have effectively controlled their costs and can maintain current level of care without additional funds; Medicare payments to hospitals totaled $84 billion last year, or 44 percent of all Medicare spending; recommendation offers Pres Clinton and Congress a relatively easy way to reduce Federal budget deficit and shore up Medicare trust; American Hospital Association spokeswoman complains that maintaining current level of hospital payments would effectively punish hospitals for improving their productivity, but Federal officials say that Medicare should share the benefits of such improvements and that hospitals can continue increasing productivity; graph (M)
docs.snippet: A Federal advisory panel has decided to recommend that Congress freeze Medicare payments to hospitals next year. It would be the first time in the history of the program that hospitals have not received an increase.    In approving the...

docs.lead_paragraph: CLINTON IS AT MIDCOURSE. WILL THERE BE A MIDCOURSE CORRECTION? A thing must first have a shape for the shape to be correctable. How does one ''correct'' a chaos? In last fall's election, though Clinton won 49 percent of the vote, according to a Time/CNN poll only 14 percent of those voting said they agreed with his positions -- and one wonders how even those few divined what those positions are. In the last half of his first term, Clinton's pliability was traced to Dick Morris, who called his strategy ''triangulation,'' a metaphor from sailing, where you tack with the wind given you, deviating from a course in order to angle back toward it. But Clinton needed no lessons in shiftiness. How do you teach a cat to twist as it falls? I am haunted by a story Lew Manilow told me. Manilow is a Clinton friend and financial backer. ''Joe Klein came up to me and poked his finger in my chest'' -- Manilow pointed his own finger at his chest, then lowered it to his belly button. (''Joe is even shorter than I am.'') Klein said: ''He turned on me, Lew. And he'll turn on you, too. Just wait and see.'' Klein had been de-Flowered, an ideological Gennifer. But while Flowers took her grievance to a tabloid for peanuts, Klein took his to Random House for millions.
docs.abstract: Garry Wills article on what Pres Clinton believes in; notes that 49 percent of Americans voted for him, but in Time/CNN poll, only 14 percent of those voting say they agreed with his positions; says Clinton ran his first campaign based on reinventing government, but he seems to have spent more time reinventing Clinton; says truth is that Clinton does not believe in big government, but he does believe strongly that some government is necessary and beneficial; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, a letter to the editor from Janice M. Cauwels on Jan. 5 about health insurance included an erroneous final sentence. The reference was to the subject of a Dec. 8 article, Sister Jane Frances Brady, chief executive officer of St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in downtown Paterson. It should have read, ''New Jersey does care about medical treatment for the poor, Sister Jane -- after all the state is dipping into their pockets to pay for it.'' (It should not have said ''the state is dipping into its pockets to pay for it.'')
